title: 114_hr771
content: The Act titled "Protecting Access to Diabetes Supplies Act of 2015" aims to strengthen rules for competition regarding diabetic testing strips. The Act "Protecting Access to Diabetes Supplies Act of 2015" strengthens rules for competition in providing diabetic testing strips, with a special rule for determining product volume through multiple data sources. The Secretary must demonstrate the ability to supply various types of diabetic testing strips. The Secretary will reject bids that do not demonstrate the ability to supply diabetic testing strips as required. The calculation of bid coverage must include a specified percentage of all types of strips. The Secretary requires bids to include a specified percentage of all types of diabetic testing strip products. Contracts with entities must ensure availability of all types of strips included in the bid. The Secretary requires bids to include a specified percentage of all types of diabetic testing strip products. Contracts with entities must ensure availability of all types of strips included in the bid. If an entity fails to fulfill the requirements, the Secretary will terminate the contract. The Secretary will monitor adherence to the demonstration provided by the entity for testing strips under the contract. The Social Security Act is being amended to include information on diabetic testing strips in contracts. Additionally, a new special rule is introduced for competition involving diabetic testing strips. The entity providing diabetic testing strips must offer the brand compatible with the individual's glucose monitor. They are prohibited from influencing or incentivizing the individual to switch brands. The entity must provide standardized information to individuals before communicating directly with them, including details about their rights and the requirements established. Individuals have the right to contact other suppliers or purchase diabetic testing strips at a retail pharmacy if the entity cannot provide the compatible brand. They also have the right to reject strips provided by the entity. The Secretary will establish a process for individuals to reject diabetic testing strips provided under the competitive acquisition program. Rejection can be done through notification to the supplier and the Secretary, with consequences outlined for such rejection. Individuals can reject diabetic testing strips provided under the competitive acquisition program. The Secretary will recover unused strips, and individuals can get different strips without coverage limitations. Individuals can reject diabetic testing strips provided under the competitive acquisition program. The supplier cannot submit additional claims for payment if strips are rejected unless the individual consents to receive the same type or brand. Effective date for amendments applies to strips furnished on or after a specified date. Effective July 1, 2016, new regulations apply to diabetic testing strips provided under the competitive acquisition program.
